node.title: Fears About the Future of Abortion
node.alt: Demonstrators for and against abortion rights outside the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday.
node.description: Readers express concern about the ramifications if Roe v. Wade is overturned. Also: Unvaccinated health workers; working remotely; hopes for Democrats.
node.content: ["To the Editor:", "Re \u201cJustices Indicate They Will Uphold Curb on Abortion\u201d (front page, Dec. 2):", "One hundred years ago, my grandmother died from sepsis after a botched street abortion. I am afraid that a reversal of Roe v. Wade will send us back to those times, leaving many women with no choice but to put themselves at great risk.", "I hope the Supreme Court will not turn into a political entity and, in doing so, destroy not only the lives of many women but itself as well.", "Marian BresselHull, Mass.", "To the Editor:", "Justice Sonia Sotomayor was correct in questioning the ability of the Supreme Court to \u201csurvive the stench\u2019\u2019 that overturning Roe would result in. The Republican appointees seem determined to ignore the established law on the matter of abortion and impose their personal religious beliefs on Americans.", "They will drag the Supreme Court into the morass of partisan politics. This disgraceful abrogation of the justices\u2019 sworn duty to uphold the Constitution should be a warning that the Republican Party cannot be trusted to govern in a responsible manner.", "Bill GottdenkerMountainside, N.J.", "To the Editor:", "In answer to Chief Justice John Roberts\u2019s question about why 15 weeks wasn\u2019t enough time to make the choice to have an abortion, I\u2019d like to give a partial answer based on my experiences as a counselor.", "An 11-year-old came in with her grandmother to learn that she was 18 weeks pregnant, not just gaining weight.", "A 38-year-old unattached professional woman came in to have a pregnancy test (at 22 weeks) and faced the distressing fact for her that she was actually pregnant, that not having periods was not early menopause.", "A wife and mother of three children learned that her husband not only was having an extramarital affair but also had two children by this other relationship. She realized that she could not cope with another child while she was making the decision to leave her husband and look for a job (some time after 15 weeks).", "I learned to listen, to not judge, to allow a woman the autonomy to know what was best for her. For some, that was the decision to abort.", "Nancy CoxOwings Mills, Md.", "To the Editor:", "It certainly doesn\u2019t give one confidence in the integrity of those justices who testified in their confirmation hearings or told senators that they would uphold precedents while on the court. They either had a wondrous enlightenment or outright lied to obtain their position. How sad.", "Ross E. McRonaldBoynton Beach, Fla.", "To the Editor:", "Re \u201cAbortion Dividing Line of Fetal Viability Faces a Supreme Court Test\u201d (news article, Nov. 29):", "There is a more accurate way of testing viability. Integrity of brain stem function has been the medical gold standard for when all human beings are considered alive. The detection of a heart rate when a patient is unresponsive, intubated and ventilated is not very helpful in determining when a human being is alive or not. Many of these patients have heart rates but are still considered to have brain death if they have no brain stem reflexes.", "If the Supreme Court justices want to be more accurate as to when a fetus becomes viable, they should look no further than this gold standard. In the past 10 years M.R.I. imaging of the fetal brain has provided very accurate information on the brain stem in a developing fetus. An intact brain stem, not heart rate, is the way we determine viability in humans outside the womb. Why should it be any different inside the womb?", "Timothy J. DunnMount Laurel, N.J.The writer is a neurologist.", "", "To the Editor:", "Re \u201cJudge Blocks Biden\u2019s Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers\u201d (news article, Dec. 1):", "Raise your hand if you want your grandparents, your parents or your children taken care of by unvaccinated health care workers.", "J.M. Weiss-RiveraMadison, Conn.The writer is a family practitioner.", "To the Editor:", "As the parent of a college graduate who started full-time work in the pandemic, I appreciate all the points made by Anne Helen Petersen and Charlie Warzel in \u201cRemote, Invisible and Failing at Work\u201d (Opinion guest essay, Sunday Review, Nov. 28).", "On more than one occasion, my daughter has told me about a confusing or irritating work situation that she finds impossible to address adequately, because she doesn\u2019t really know the people on her team \u2014 she\u2019s never been alongside them in an office, seeing and learning that culture. My ability to offer advice is limited, because I\u2019ve never experienced a \u201cworkplace\u201d like the one she has.", "New employees need support in myriad ways that go far beyond what a manager might see as job duties. It\u2019s up to workers who remember gathering around a coffee pot or refrigerator, talking about their weekends, to help create similar situations for their new co-workers, so those newbies can really feel they are part of the team.", "Paula ChambersRichmond, Va.", "To the Editor:", "Re \u201cDemocrats Shouldn\u2019t Panic. They Should Go Into Shock,\u201d by Thomas B. Edsall (Opinion guest essay, nytimes.com, Nov. 17):", "Sure, people are currently feeling insecurity about the economy and both fatigue and concern about Covid, and sure, they feel embarrassed by the Afghanistan withdrawal. But things change in a year.", "There is substantial reason to feel that the economy is going to take a fiery turn for the better, that the pandemic will be well controlled by then and that memories, to some degree, will fade about Afghanistan by the time of the next election.", "Further, with the prospect of an energizing adverse ruling on Roe v. Wade, as well as Stacey Abrams\u2019s entry into the Georgia governor\u2019s race, there is reason to be hopeful about the Democrats\u2019 prospects.", "Buck up, Dems.", "James A. SteinbergRhinebeck, N.Y."]
